THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Supreme Court

	
		
			
				Sherrie
      Lazicki-Thomas, Appellant,
				v.
				South Carolina Budget and Control Board, South Carolina Retirement Systems, Respondent.
			
		
	


Appeal from Richland County
Â Ralph K. Anderson, III, Administrative Law Court Judge

Opinion No.Â  26487
Heard March 19, 2008 - Filed May 12, 2008Â  
AFFIRMED


	
		
			
				Robert
  E. Hoskins, of Foster Law Firm, of Greenville, and Robertson H. Wendt, Jr., of North Charleston, for Appellant.
				Kelly
  H. Rainsford, and David K. Avant, both of South Carolina Retirement Systems, of
  Columbia, for Respondent.
			
		
	


JUSTICE PLEICONES:Â  The issue in this appeal
  is whether the Administrative Law Court (ALC) correctly interpreted the meaning
  of the phrase â€œmember in serviceâ€ in the Police Officers Retirement System
  (PORS) disability statute[1] to mean a member who is still an employee.Â  We hold the phrase was properly
  construed and affirm.
FACTS
Appellant
  was employed as a City of North Charleston firefighter, accruing five years,
  three months, and sixteen days of service credit in the PORS.Â  In April 2004,
  she was allegedly injured on the job, and as of January 28, 2005, her city
  employment was terminated.Â  Appellant filed an application for disability
  retirement on August 16, 2005, and respondent promptly notified her that she
  was ineligible to apply because she was not â€œin serviceâ€ when the application
  was made.Â  Following exhaustion of her administrative remedies and a final
  determination by respondent, appellant filed a request for a contested case
  hearing with the ALC.
In
  August 2006, while appellantâ€™s case was pending, the ALC sitting en banc issued an order in a case entitled Anderson v. S.C. Budget &
    Control Bd., S.C. Retirement Sys. In Anderson, the ALC interpreted
  the phrase â€œmember in serviceâ€ in the South Carolina Retirement System (SCRS)
  disability retirement statute.[2]Â 
  The ALC held that the phrase â€œas applied to an employee seeking disability
  retirement benefits, plainly means a person having the status of an employeeâ€¦at
  the time the application for disability benefits is filed, specifically
  including those on accrued annual leave or sick leave.â€Â  In reaching this
  decision, the ALC relied in part on the legislative histories of the PORS
  disability retirement statute and the Retirement System for Members of the
  General Assembly disability statute,[3] both of which contain language identical to that in the SCRS statute, i.e.,
  â€œthe application of a member in service.â€Â  The parties and the ALC agree the Anderson order applies to disability applicants under all three retirement
  systems.
Following
  the filing of the Anderson order, respondent was granted summary
  judgment.Â  This appeal follows.
ISSUE

	Whether
  a disability retirement application is untimely if not filed while the applicant
  is a member in service?

ANALYSIS
The PORS disability
  retirement statute contains the following provision:

	On the
  application of a member in service or the memberâ€™s employer, a member who
  has five or more completed years of earned service or any contributing member
  who is disabled as a result of an injury arising out of and in the course of
  the performance of the memberâ€™s duties regardless of length of membership may
  be retired by the retirement board not less than thirty days and not more than
  nine months next following the date of filing the application on a disability
  retirement allowance if the system, after a medical examination of the member,
  certifies that the member is mentally or physically incapacitated for the
  further performance of duty, that the incapacity is likely to be permanent, and
  that the member should be retired.
	Â§
  9-11-80(1) (emphasis supplied).

The ALC found that
  there was no need to resort of the rules of statutory construction to determine
  the meaning of the term â€œin serviceâ€ as the language was clear, plain and
  unambiguous, and meant that the member was an employee at the time the
  disability application was filed.Â  See Ventures South Carolina, LLC
    v. S.C. Depâ€™t of Rev., Op No. 26486 (S.C. Sup. Ct. filed May 12, 2008)
  (â€œwhere language is plain and unambiguous â€¦ the rules of statutory
  interpretation are not neededâ€).
Appellant
  contends the ALC erred in finding the disability retirement statute
  unambiguous.Â  Her focus is not on the term â€œmember in service,â€ but rather the
  event to which it applies.Â  She reads the statute to require that the
  disability arise during employment, and to be silent on the time for filing the
  application.Â  We disagree.
The
  PORS disability statute begins with the clause â€œOn the application of a member
  in service,â€ an unambiguous reference to the application process. The timing of
  the disabling event is found later in the sentence, with disability retirement
  available to a member with five or more completed years of earned service who
  becomes disabled for any reason, or to any contributing member with less than
  the five years â€œwho is disabled as a result of an injury arising out of and in
  the course of the performance of the memberâ€™s duties . . . .â€Â  Â That the
  disabling event and the application must both occur while the person is still
  employed is evident from the procedural language at the conclusion of the
  statute which states the applicant â€œmay be retiredâ€¦if the systemâ€¦certifies that
  the member should be retired.â€Â  A person who is no longer working for the
  entity cannot â€œbe retiredâ€ from that agency.Â  We find no support for
  appellantâ€™s assertion that the statuteâ€™s opening phrase â€œOn the application of
  a member in serviceâ€ merely qualifies the timing of the disabling event rather
  than defining the application period.
The
  disability retirement statutes mandate that the application be filed by a
  â€œmember in service.â€Â  Appellant was not in service when her application was
  filed, and respondentâ€™s summary judgment motion was properly granted.Â 
  Therefore, the order on appeal is
AFFIRMED.
TOAL, C.J.,
  WALLER, BEATTY, JJ. and Acting Justice E. C. Burnett, III, concur.




[1] S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 9-11-80 (1985 & Supp. 2007).
[2] S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 9-1-1540 (Supp. 2007).Â  
[3] S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 9-9-65(1) (Supp. 2007).

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Supreme Court

	
		
			
				The State, Respondent,
				v.
				Cedric Emmanuel
      Perkins, Appellant.
			
		
	

Appeal from Greenville County
Â Charles B. Simmons, Jr., Circuit Court
  Judge
Opinion No. 26490
Heard April 3, 2008 - Filed May 12, 2008Â Â  
AFFIRMED


	
		
			
				Kenneth
  Clifton Gibson, of Greenville, for Appellant.
				Solicitor
  Robert M. Ariail, Deputy Solicitor Betty C. Strom, of Greenville, for
  Respondent.
			
		
	


CHIEF
  JUSTICE TOAL: In this case, Appellant
  Cedric Perkins was terminated from the Thirteenth Circuit Drug Court Program, and
  the trial court imposed Appellantâ€™s suspended sentence.Â  Appellant argues
  positive â€œsweat patchâ€ drug tests and certain
  violations should not have been considered in the decision to terminate
  Appellant from the Drug Court Program.Â  We affirm.
Factual/Procedural Background

The Thirteenth
  Circuit Drug Court Program (hereinafter â€œDrug Court Programâ€ or â€œProgramâ€) is a
  voluntary therapeutic program which may be offered to a defendant that is
  charged with a drug abuse offense within the thirteenth circuit jurisdiction.Â 
  The defendant pleads guilty to the charge and agrees with the solicitor to
  enter the Program.Â  As a result, the trial court imposes a sentence on the defendant,
  but suspends the sentence, conditioned upon the successful completion the Program.Â 
  The participant agrees to abide by certain terms and conditions of
  participation and may be sanctioned or ultimately terminated for failure to
  comply with the terms of the Program.Â  
In
  the instant case, Appellant pled guilty to possession with intent to distribute
  crack cocaine.Â  The trial court sentenced him to ten years imprisonment,
  suspended upon his successful completion of the Drug Court Program.Â  Appellant entered
  the Program on September 13, 2002.Â  On September 25, 2003, after numerous
  violations, Appellant met with the Programâ€™s chief administrator where she told
  Appellant that he could remain in the Program so long as he had no more
  violations.Â  However, Appellant subsequently tested positive for drugs, and on
  October 12, 2003, program administrators recommended his termination.[1]Â 
  Following a hearing, the trial court issued an order terminating Appellant from
  the Program and imposing his original sentence.Â  

Appellant
  appealed the trial courtâ€™s order.Â  This Court certified the appeal pursuant to
  Rule 204(b), SCACR, and Appellant presents the following issues for review:

	Did the
  lower court wrongfully terminate Appellant from the Drug Court Program?[2]

Law/Analysis
Appellant argues that
  he was wrongfully terminated from the Drug Court Program.Â  Because undertaking
  such a review would require that this Court evaluate and assess the manner in
  which the Programâ€™s administrators execute the rules and regulations of the
  Program - an inquiry over which this Court has no authority - we decline to
  answer this question.
Several counties
  across the State have implemented Drug Court Programs similar to the Thirteenth
  Circuit Drug Court Program.Â  These Programs are aimed at rehabilitating the
  participant and helping him overcome addiction, but the specific manner in
  which each Drug Court Program operates varies.Â  For example, under the
  procedures of other Programs, a social worker, a magistrate, or a Drug Court team member may terminate the participant from the Program.Â  However, pursuant to
  the Thirteenth Circuit Drug Court Program procedures, Program administrators
  recommend a participant for termination, and the trial court decides whether to
  terminate a participant from the Program.Â  
We
  decline to review whether Appellantâ€™s positive sweat patch results or
  violations occurring after the meeting with the chief administrator were
  properly considered in the decision to terminate Appellant from the Drug Court
  Program.Â  In our view, it would be improper for the judiciary to interject
  itself into such matters which are wholly internal and specific to each Program
  and to each participant.Â  To do so would transform the Drug Court Programs into
  a judicially-supervised institution.Â  Thus, in order to assess what issues Appellant
  may appeal and what issues this Court may review, it is necessary to begin by
  clarifying the judicial determinations below.
After
  Appellantâ€™s guilty plea, the trial court sentenced Appellant to ten years
  imprisonment, but suspended the imposition of that sentence conditioned upon
  the successful completion of the Drug Court Program.Â  Thus, the trial courtâ€™s
  imposition of his original sentence after being terminated from the Drug Court
  Program deprived Appellant of a conditional liberty interest, and thereby
  entitled him due process rights.Â  See Dangerfield
    v. State, 376
  S.C. 176,Â Â Â Â Â Â  , 656 S.E.2d 352, 355 (2008)
  (holding that the imposition of a suspended sentence deprived the defendant of
  a conditional liberty interest and implicated the defendantâ€™s due process
  rights).Â  Therefore, like any other defendant who is
  subject to the imposition of a suspended sentence, we conclude that a Drug
  Court Program participant is entitled to notice and a hearing to determine
  whether he has violated the conditions of his suspended sentence before his
  sentence may be imposed.Â  See id. (holding that due process required
  notice and a hearing on the willfulness of the defendantâ€™s failure to pay
  restitution before imposition of a suspended sentence).Â  Accordingly, while we
  hold that it is inappropriate for the courts to review whether a participant
  was properly terminated from a Drug Court Program, the participant is
  entitled to a hearing to determine whether he was in fact terminated from a
  Drug Court Program (i.e., whether the defendant violated a condition of his
  suspended sentence) before his sentence may be imposed.[3]
The
  decision of whether a defendant has violated a condition of his suspended
  sentence rests within the sound discretion of the trial court. Â See State v. Miller, 122 S.C. 468, 474-75, 115 S.E. 742, 745 (1923)
  (holding that the nature of the inquiry and extent of the
  investigation to be conducted by a lower court in determining whether the
  condition of a suspended sentence has been violated are matters that rest in
  the sound discretion of that court). Â An
  appellate court will not reverse the trial courtâ€™s decision unless that court
  abused its discretion.Â  See State v. Allen, 370
  S.C. 88, 94, 634 S.E.2d 653, 655 (2006)
  (addressing the applicable standards of review in a probation revocation
  hearing).
In the instant case, it is undisputed that a condition of
  Appellantâ€™s suspended sentence was the successful completion of the Drug Court
  Program and that Appellant was terminated from the Program.Â  Thus, the trial
  court correctly determined that Appellant violated a condition of his suspended
  sentence, and therefore, properly imposed Appellantâ€™s original sentence.Â  Accordingly,
  we must uphold the imposition of Appellantâ€™s sentence.Â  
Conclusion
For
  the foregoing reasons, we affirm the trial courtâ€™s order imposing Appellantâ€™s
  original sentence.Â  
MOORE,
  WALLER, BEATTY, JJ., and Acting Justice Diane Schafer Goodstein, concur.


[1] Appellant was sanctioned eighteen times while in the Program.Â  Appellantâ€™s
  violations included positive drug tests, missed drug tests, tardiness for court
  appearances, missed appointments with program administrators, and failure to
  pay fees.Â  
[2] Specifically, Appellant argues that the lower court wrongfully terminated him
  from the Program because it erred in considering positive drug test results
  from â€œsweat patchesâ€ when the Drug Court Programâ€™s contract did not provide for
  such testing methods and erred in considering violations that occurred prior to
  the September 25, 2003 meeting with the Programâ€™s chief administrator.
[3] That the trial court in the instant case had the authority, pursuant to the Thirteenth
  Circuit Program rules, to terminate Appellant from the Program and also had
  subject matter jurisdiction to impose Appellantâ€™s suspended sentence and
  memorialized these decisions in the same order is irrelevant to our scope of
  review.Â  We note that although magistrates, social workers, or Drug Court team members in other Programs determine whether to terminate the participant,
  these bodies do not have the authority to impose the suspended sentence.Â  A
  terminated participant should always be afforded a hearing before the proper
  tribunal with the authority to impose a suspended sentence.Â

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Supreme Court

	
		
			
				Delmore Cain, Appellant,
				v.
				Nationwide
      Property and Casualty Insurance Company, Respondent.
			
		
	


Appeal From Richland County
Â G. Thomas Cooper, Jr., Circuit Court
  Judge
Opinion No. 26491
Heard April 3, 2008 - Filed May 12, 2008Â Â  
AFFIRMED


	
		
			
				Gary W.
  Popwell, Jr., of Lee, Eadon, Isgett & Popwell, of Columbia, for Appellant.
				J.R.
  Murphy, of Murphy & Grantland, of Columbia, for Respondent.
			
		
	


JUSTICE
  BEATTY:Â  In this insurance case, Delmore Cain appeals the circuit courtâ€™s
  order denying him uninsured motorist proceeds pursuant to a compensation
  section in the South Carolina Tort Claims Act.Â  We affirm.
FACTS

The parties essentially agree to the facts of this case, leaving
  the Court solely with a matter of statutory construction.Â  
On April 21, 2003, the work vehicle in which Delmore Cain was a
  passenger was hit head-on by a Richland County dump truck that crossed the
  center line.Â  Cain suffered serious injuries to his head, chest, hips, and
  legs, which will require years of medical treatment and caused him â€œphysical
  pain, suffering, mental anguish, emotional distress and impairment of health
  and bodily efficiency.â€Â  Cain sought damages for his injuries and future
  medical costs against Richland County.Â  Richland County carried insurance on
  the dump truck in an amount exceeding the minimum limits required by law.Â  The
  parties settled the lawsuit, and Cain received $300,000, which is the maximum
  amount allowed under the South Carolina Tort Claims Act.[1]Â  He also received $40,000 from the
  underinsured motorist coverage policy covering the vehicle in which he was a
  passenger.Â  
The
  parties to the underlying case stipulate Cainâ€™s damages exceeded $370,000.Â  At
  the time of the accident, Cain was covered under an automobile policy issued by
  Nationwide Property and Casualty Insurance Company that contained uninsured
  motorist coverage in the amount of $15,000 per person for each insured vehicle.Â 
  The policy holder specifically refused underinsured motorist coverage.[2]Â  The policy defined â€œuninsured motor
  vehicleâ€ as one which does not have liability coverage in the minimum amounts
  required by the law where the insuredâ€™s car is principally located.Â  The policy
  went on to state that Nationwide does not consider as an uninsured vehicle:Â  a
  motor vehicle owned by the government or an agency; or a vehicle defined as
  underinsured.Â  The policy defined â€œunderinsured motor vehicleâ€ as one for which
  liability coverage meets the minimum amounts required by law but is in an
  amount less than the insuredâ€™s damages.Â  
The underlying claim[3] arose when Cain filed a declaratory judgment action against Nationwide to
  determine whether Nationwide was required to pay $30,000 in uninsured motorist
  coverage for Cainâ€™s remaining damages pursuant to the Tort Claims Act and
  section 15-78-190 of the South Carolina Code.Â  
After a
  hearing on the declaratory judgment action, the circuit court issued an order
  in favor of Nationwide.Â  Noting Cainâ€™s admission that he did not have
  underinsured motorist coverage, the court found the dump truck did not meet the
  definition of an â€œuninsuredâ€ vehicle under either the policy or under the
  automobile insurance statute.Â  In interpreting section 15-78-190, the court
  also held Cain was not entitled to uninsured motorist coverage.Â  Cain
  appealed.Â  The Court of Appeals certified the case to this Court.
DISCUSSION
Cain first argues the circuit court erred in interpreting section
  15-78-190.Â  He asserts the statute:Â  (1) should be read as a separate and
  distinct requirement of insurance carriers; (2) was intended to assuage the
  hardship on a plaintiff who cannot be fully compensated because damages exceed
  the statutory cap in Tort Claims Act cases; and (3) was not merely a
  restatement of an injured partyâ€™s right to obtain compensation under his
  uninsured and underinsured motorist coverage.Â  Cain also argues the court erred
  in turning to the definitions found within the insurance statutes and his
  uninsured motorist policy to determine he could not recover under section
  15-78-190.Â  Because these two issues deal with interrelated matters, we have
  addressed them as one in this discussion.
The
  primary purpose in interpreting statutes is to ascertain the intent of the
  Legislature.Â  Hodges v. Rainey, 341 S.C. 79, 85, 533 S.E.2d 578, 581
  (2000).Â  â€œWe cannot construe a statute without regard to its plain and ordinary
  meaning, and this Court may not resort to subtle or forced construction in an
  attempt to limit or expand a statuteâ€™s scope.â€Â  New York Times Co. v. Spartanburg   County Sch. Dist. No. 7, 374 S.C. 307, 310, 649 S.E.2d 28, 29-30 (2007).Â 
  â€œWhere the statuteâ€™s language is plain and unambiguous, and conveys a clear and
  definite meaning, the rules of statutory interpretation are not needed and the
  court has no right to impose another meaning.â€Â  Hodges, 341 S.C. at 85,
  533 S.E.2d at 581.Â  The statuteâ€™s language is considered the best evidence of
  legislative intent.Â  Id.Â  However, the Court will reject the plain
  meaning of the words used in a statute if it would lead to an absurd result and
  will â€œconstrue the statute so as to escape the absurdity and carry the
  intention into effect.â€Â  Ray
    Bell Constr. Co. v. Sch. Dist. of Greenville County, 331
  S.C. 19, 26, 501 S.E.2d 725, 729 (1998).Â  Further, when a plain reading of the
  statute â€œlends itself to two equally logical interpretations, this Court must
  apply the rules of statutory interpretation to resolve the ambiguity and to
  discover the intent of the General Assembly.â€Â  Kennedy v. South Carolina Ret. Sys., 345 S.C. 339, 348, 549 S.E.2d 243, 247 (2001). 
Section 15-78-190, which is part of the Tort Claims Act, is
  encaptioned:Â  â€œCompensation of plaintiff pursuant to underinsured or uninsured defendant provisions of plaintiffâ€™s insurance policy.â€[4] Â (emphasis added).Â  The section
  states, in relevant part, as follows:

	If the amount of the verdict or judgment is not satisfied by
  reason of the monetary limitations of this chapter upon recovery from the State
  or political subdivision thereof, the plaintiffâ€™s insurance company, subject
    to the underinsured and uninsured defendant provisions of the plaintiffâ€™s
    insurance policy, if any, shall compensate the plaintiff for the difference between the amount of the verdict or judgment and the payment by the political
  subdivision.Â  If a cause of action is barred under Â§ 15-78-60 of the 1976 Code,
  the plaintiffâ€™s insurance company must compensate him for his losses subject to
  the aforementioned provisions of his insurance policy.

S.C. Code Ann. Â§
  15-78-190 (2005) (emphasis added).Â  
A clear reading of the statute shows that the purpose is to allow
  injured parties with damages above the statutory cap in the Tort Claims Act to
  obtain further compensation.Â  While Cain argues the statute was intended to
  compensate all persons with damages above the statutory cap in a Tort Claims
  Act case, regardless of whether they meet the statutory or policy definitions
  for uninsured or underinsured defendant coverage, we take the more limited view
  that it was intended only to allow compensation where the definitions were met.Â  
Section 15-78-20 contains the declaration of public policy for the
  enactment of the Tort Claims Act and states that â€œ[t]he remedy provided by this
  chapter is the exclusive civil remedy available for any tort committed
  by a governmental entity, its employees, or its agents except as provided in Â§
  15-78-70(b).â€Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 15-78-20(b) (2005) (emphasis added).Â  While limiting
  recovery under the Tort Claims Act as the sole method of obtaining compensation from the government is not unusual, the uninsured motorist and
  underinsured motorist insurance arena is unique.Â  Certainly, the sole purpose
  of the existence of these kinds of insurance is to provide compensation where
  the at-fault motorist either is not insured or does not have enough insurance.Â 
  Thus, by enacting section 15-78-190, the Legislature assured that an insurance
  company could not cite the â€œexclusive civil remedyâ€ portion of section 15-78-20
  to deny payment from the plaintiffâ€™s uninsured or underinsured motorist
  coverage where recovery pursuant to the Tort Claims Act was insufficient.Â  Injured
  parties are free to seek recovery under their underinsured or uninsured
  motorist policies any time recovery from the at-fault motorist is insufficient,
  and section 15-78-190 was specifically intended to inform insurance companies that
  nothing changes when an at-fault government vehicle is involved.Â  Thus, the
  enactment of this section, which appears to restate portions of other sections
  in the Insurance Code, was not redundant.[5]Â  Steinke v. S.C. Depâ€™t of Labor, Licensing, & Regulation, 336 S.C.
  373, 396, 520 S.E.2d 142, 154 (1999) (â€œWhile provisions establishing
  limitations upon and exemptions from liability of a governmental entity must be
  liberally construed to limit liability, we also must presume in construing a
  statute that the Legislature did not intend to perform a futile thing.â€). Â 
Considering
  the facts of this case, 15-78-190 would be applicable if an uninsured or
  underinsured at-fault government vehicle is involved.Â  Both â€œunderinsured
  motoristâ€ and â€œuninsured motoristâ€ are terms statutorily defined in the
  Insurance Code.[6]Â 
  Section 15-78-190 provides that recovery is â€œsubject toâ€ the terms of the
  insuredâ€™s underinsured or uninsured policy.Â  Thus, in order to recover, the
  plaintiff must first meet the requirements and terms found both in the statute
  and within the policy, assuming the policy provisions do not violate the law or
  public policy of this State.Â  In most instances, this will necessarily limit
  recovery to an injured party who meets the definitions.Â  
Turning to the instant case, we agree with the circuit court that
  Cain was not entitled to recover under the â€œuninsured motoristâ€ section of his
  policy.Â  Strictly applying the statutory and policy definitions, it is apparent
  that the dump truck was an â€œunderinsuredâ€ vehicle because the dump truck had
  insurance protection greater than the minimum limits but less than Cainâ€™s
  damages.[7]Â 
  Cain admitted that he did not have â€œunderinsured motoristâ€ coverage on his
  policy.Â  Because recovery under section 15-78-190 is subject to the
  requirements in his policy, Cain failed to meet the definitions and cannot
  recover.Â  
CONCLUSION
While
  we sympathize with Cainâ€™s need for further compensation, we cannot ignore the
  clear meaning attached to the terms â€œunderinsuredâ€ and â€œuninsuredâ€ contained
  within section 15-78-190.Â  It is evident the Legislature intended this section
  to prevent insurers from denying further compensation above amounts recovered
  pursuant to the Tort Claims Act.Â  Thus, it does not change the fact that
  recovery is limited to situations where the policy terms are met.Â  Accordingly,
  the circuit courtâ€™s order denying recovery is
AFFIRMED.
TOAL,
  C.J., MOORE, WALLER, JJ., and Acting Justice Diane Schafer Goodstein, concur.


[1]Â 
  The South Carolina Tort Claims Act caps liability for damages caused by a
  governmental agency at $300,000 for a single occurrence.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§
  15-78-120(a)(1) (2005).Â  
[2]Â 
  The policy was issued to Lekettia Pough and it included Cain as one of the
  named drivers.Â  Â Â 
[3]Â 
  Brenda Cain, Delmoreâ€™s wife, was also a passenger in the vehicle and also
  suffered serious injuries.Â  Although she was a party in the lawsuit against Richland Cou  nty, she was not a party in the underlying claim against Nationwide.Â  
[4]Â 
  It is interesting to note that Act 463, enacting the Tort Claims Act, just
  listed this section as â€œPlaintiff to be compensated.â€Â  1986 S.C. Acts 463, Â§
  6.Â  
[5]Â  See S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 38-77-150 (2002) (providing that an insured may
  select â€œuninsured motorist coverageâ€ and proceed under the section to obtain
  damages from the owner of an uninsured vehicle); S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 38-77-160
  (2002) (providing recovery under â€œunderinsured motorist coverageâ€).Â  
[6]Â  Similar to the definition
  found in the Nationwide policy, our Legislature has defined an â€œunderinsured
  motor vehicleâ€ as one where â€œthere is bodily injury liability insurance or a
  bond applicable at the time of the accident in an amount of at least that
  specified in Section 38-77-140 and the amount of the insurance or bond is less
  than the amount of the insuredâ€™s damages.â€Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 38-77-30(15)
  (2002).Â  An â€œuninsured motor vehicleâ€ is one as to which:

	(a)Â  there is not bodily injury liability insurance and property
  damage liability insurance both at least in the amounts specified in Section
  38-77-140, or
	(b)Â  there is nominally that insurance, but the insurer writing
  the same successfully denies coverage thereunder, or
	(c)Â  there was that insurance, but the insurer who wrote the same
  is declared insolvent, or is in delinquency proceedings, suspension, or
  receivership, or is proven unable fully to respond to a judgment, and
	(d)Â  there is no bond or deposit of cash or securities in lieu of
  the bodily injury and property damage liability insurance.
	(e)Â  the owner of the motor vehicle has not qualified as a
  self-insurer in accordance with the applicable provisions of law.
	. . .
	Any motor vehicle owned by the State or any of its
  political subdivisions is considered an uninsured motor vehicle when the
  vehicle is operated by a person without proper authorization.Â  

S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 38-77-30(14) (2002).Â  
[7]Â 
  In fact, Cain stipulates in his brief that the dump truck does not meet either
  definition of an â€œuninsuredâ€ vehicle.Â  He argues, however, that it does not
  matter for purposes of recovery under section 15-78-190.Â

description: This order dismisses the notice of appeal from an order denying petitioner's PCR application because the issue petitioner seeks to raise, waiver of his right to direct appeal, is successive.

The Supreme Court of South Carolina

  
    
      
        
          David Wayne Graham, Petitioner,
        
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
        
          State of South Carolina, Respondent.
        
      
    
  


ORDER

Petitioner pled guilty  to murder, armed robbery, and criminal conspiracy.  No direct appeal was taken.
 Petitioner filed an application for  post-conviction relief (PCR) in which he alleged his guilty plea was  involuntary, counsel was ineffective, and the evidence was insufficient.  The application was denied and dismissed.  Petitioner’s petition for a writ of  certiorari was denied by this Court after review pursuant to Johnson v.  State, 294 S.C. 310, 364 S.E.2d 201 (1988). 
Petitioner  filed a second PCR application in which the denial of his right to direct  appeal was the sole issue raised.  The  PCR judge found the application was successive and barred by the statute of  limitations.
Petitioner has now filed a  notice of appeal and an explanation, pursuant to Rule 227(c), SCACR, why the  PCR judge’s findings were improper.   Specifically, petitioner contends his request for a belated review of  his direct appeal issues pursuant to White v. State, 263 S.C. 110, 208  S.E.2d 35 (1974) and Davis v. State, 288 S.C. 290, 342 S.E.2d 60 (1986) was not successive and was not abandoned by  prior proceedings.  Petitioner argues  further that the memorandum he submitted to the lower court set forth  meritorious appellate issues.   Accordingly, petitioner maintains he should be allowed his “full bite at  the apple.”
 Initially, we note the PCR judge erred in finding  petitioner’s second application was barred by the statute of limitations.  Wilson v. State, 348 S.C. 215, 559 S.E.2d 581 (2002)(one year statute of  limitations for PCR claims does not apply to allegation applicant was denied  the right to direct appeal due to the ineffective assistance of counsel).  However, he did not err in finding the  application was successive.  
 All  applicants are entitled to a full and fair opportunity to present claims in one  PCR application.  Odom v. State,  337 S.C. 256, 523 S.E.2d 753 (1999).  Successive  PCR applications and appeals are generally disfavored because they allow an  applicant to receive more than “one bite at the apple as it were.”  Id.  A successive PCR application is one that  raises grounds not raised in a prior application, raises grounds previously  heard and determined, or raises grounds  waived in prior proceedings.  Id.  In order to be entitled to a successive PCR  application, the applicant must establish that the grounds raised in the  subsequent application could not have been raised in the previous application.  Id.  
 In  the case at hand, petitioner clearly could have raised the issue of the denial  of his right to direct appeal in his first PCR application.  Because petitioner failed to raise the issue  in his first application, the PCR judge correctly found petitioner was barred  from raising it in a successive application.   Accordingly, because petitioner has failed to provide a sufficient  explanation, as required by Rule 227(c), why the PCR judge’s finding that the  application was barred as successive was improper, we hereby dismiss  petitioner’s appeal. 
IT  IS SO ORDERED.

title: Town of Summerville v. City of North Charleston
description: This is a direct appeal from a grant of partial summary judgment to the City of North Charleston.  The issue on appeal is whether the Town of Summerville complied with a statute which requires the publication of notice not less than thirty days prior to acting on a petition to annex real property.  Finding that notice did not occur at least thirty days prior to acting on the petition to annex, the Court affirmed.

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Supreme Court

	
		
			
				Town of Summerville, Appellant,
				v.
				City of North Charleston, Respondent.
			
		
	


Appeal from Dorchester County
Â James C. Williams, Jr., Circuit Court
  Judge
Opinion No. 26492
Heard April 2, 2008 - Filed May 19, 2008Â Â  
AFFIRMED


	
		
			
				Jack
  M. Scoville, Jr., of Georgetown, for Appellant.
				Derk
  Van Raalte and J. Brady Hair, both of North Charleston, for Respondent.
			
		
	


JUSTICE
  PLEICONES:Â  This is a direct appeal
  from a grant of partial summary judgment to the City of North Charleston.Â  The
  issue on appeal is whether the Town of Summerville complied with a statute
  which requires the publication of notice not less than thirty days prior to
  acting on a petition to annex real property.Â  Because the Town of Summerville did not comply with the statute, we affirm.
FACTS
This
  is an annexation dispute between neighboring municipalities.Â  At some point in
  2005, both the Town of Summerville and the City of North Charleston desired to
  annex a portion of real property known as the Barry Tract.Â  In April 2005,
  Summerville enacted an ordinance declaring the Barry Tract annexed.Â  Believing
  Summervilleâ€™s annexation to be invalid, North Charleston enacted its annexation
  ordinance in June 2005.Â  The municipalities sued each other, and the cases were
  consolidated for trial.
The
  record reflects that both municipalities utilized the annexation procedure set
  forth in S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 5-3-150 (2004), which originates with a petition initiated
  by the owners of the property sought to be annexed.Â  The statute provides that
  annexation is complete upon the enactment of an ordinance and requires the
  annexing municipality to publish notice of a public hearing â€œnot less than thirty
  days before acting on an annexation petition . . . .â€Â  Id.Â  North Charleston moved for summary judgment on the question whether thirty days elapsed
  between April 28, 2005, the date Summerville published notice of its hearing,
  and May 27, 2005, the date Summerville enacted its annexation ordinance.Â  The
  trial court held that thirty days had not elapsed in this period, and
  Summerville appealed.Â  We certified the appeal from the court of appeals
  pursuant to Rule 204(b), SCACR.

ISSUE

	Did
  the trial court err in holding that less than thirty days elapsed between April
  28, 2005, and May 27, 2005?

STANDARD OF REVIEW
When reviewing a
  grant of summary judgment, an appellate court applies the same standard used by
  the trial court.Â  Lanham v. Blue Cross and Blue Shield of S.C., Inc.,
  349 S.C. 356, 361, 536 S.E.2d 331, 333 (2002).Â  A grant of summary judgment is
  proper when there is no genuine issue as to any material fact and the moving
  party is entitled to judgment as a matter of law.Â  Rule 56(c), SCRCP; Tupper v. Dorchester County, 326 S.C. 318, 325, 487 S.E.2d 187, 191 (1997).Â  Determining the proper
  interpretation of a statute is a question of law, and this Court reviews
  questions of law de novo.Â  Catawba Indian Tribe v. State, 372 S.C. 519,
  524, 642 S.E.2d 751, 753 (2007).
ANALYSIS
Summerville argues
  that under a plausible construction of the annexation statute at issue, a â€œdayâ€
  can be measured by the lapse of twenty-four hours from a relevant time.Â  Put in
  terms of the statute at issue, Summerville argues that Â§ 5-3-150 requires that
  a municipality publish notice of a public hearing not less than thirty
  twenty-four hour periods prior to acting on an annexation petition.Â 
  Summerville argues that it enacted its annexation ordinance at 5:30 p.m., May
  27, and that counting the days that elapsed by twenty-four hour periods, the
  twenty-ninth day prior to its enacting the ordinance ended at 5:30 p.m., April
  28, 2005.Â  Summerville therefore posits that if the notification in the
  newspaper occurred at 5:00 a.m. the morning of April 28, it occurred midway
  through the thirtieth day and complied with the annexation statuteâ€™s notice
  requirement.Â  We disagree.
Summervilleâ€™s
  argument fails on its own terms.Â  Assuming that the lapse of thirty sequential
  twenty-four hour periods provides the measuring stick, 5:30 p.m., May 27, and
  5:00 a.m., April 28, are separated by 29 days, 12 hours, and 30 minutes.Â  Converting
  thirty days to a number of hours of required notice, the statute would then
  mandate that notice be published â€œnot less than [720 hours] before acting on an
  annexation petition . . . .â€Â  Id.Â  In this case, publication and action
  were separated by 708 hours, 30 minutes.Â  As a quantitative reality, this is
  less than thirty days.[1]
In fact, S.C. Code
  Ann. Â§ 15-29-10 (2005) provides a specific method for computing time for
  publication of notices.Â  The statute provides that â€œ[t]he time for publication
  of legal notices shall be computed so as to exclude the first day of
  publication and include the day on which the act or event, of which notice is
  given, is to happen or which completes the full period required for
  publication.â€Â  Id.Â  Using this method, April 28, the day of publication,
  is excluded.Â  Counting forward, May 27 is twenty-nine days from the publication
  of the notice.Â  Thus, using the statutory counting method for legal notices, we
  conclude that Summerville did not comply with the relevant public notice
  requirement in this case.
The parties offer
  additional arguments on alternative methods of counting time, but those
  arguments are largely inconsequential.Â  North Charleston posits that
  Summervilleâ€™s argument fails even under its own ordinance dealing with
  computation of time.Â  While North Charleston is correct, it is clear that a
  local ordinance cannot, absent some authorization or directive, control how
  time is computed under a state statute.Â  Similarly, this Courtâ€™s rules contain
  procedures for computing time, see Rule 6, SCRCP and Rule 234,
  SCACR, and while these rules unquestionably apply in their respective spheres,
  they are neither dispositive nor are they helpful in answering the question at
  hand.Â  In this case, a statute requires that published notice precede a public
  meeting by a specific time period, and a separate statute specifically explains
  how time is to be computed for the publication of legal notices.Â  
Summervilleâ€™s more
  basic argument about how a â€œdayâ€ is defined is not supported by our precedent.Â 
  We have held that â€œ[t]he word â€˜day,â€™ in its common acceptation, means a civil
  day of twenty-four hours, beginning and ending at midnight,â€ Corwin v.
    Comptroller Gen., 6 S.C. 390, 399 (1875), and that â€œ[f]ractions of days are
  not recognized in our laws.â€Â  Williams v. Halford, 64 S.C. 396, 402, 42
  S.E. 187, 189 (1902).Â  Corwin interprets the word â€œdayâ€ in the
  context of the South Carolina Constitutionâ€™s requirement that the Governor veto
  and return a bill or resolution within three days (Sundays excepted) or the
  bill shall become law,[2] and Williams dealt with the predecessor to Rule 6(a), SCRCPâ€™s rule on
  computation of time, found in the 1893 Code of Civil Procedure at Â§ 407.Â  These
  cases instruct that where a time requirement does not speak in terms of
  specific hour periods, the Court will not interpret a day to mean anything
  other than a calendar day.Â  See also Cleveland
    v. Calvert, 54 S.C. 83, 86, 31 S.E. 871, 872 (1899) (applying Â§ 421 of the
  1893 Code, the predecessor of the current publication statute, and concluding
  that notice appearing twenty-one days prior to action complied with statutory
  requirement of three weeksâ€™ notice).Â  We adhere to this pronouncement, and note
  that where the legislature desires for the passage of a specific number of
  hours to precede an action, it has shown a propensity for writing precisely
  such a requirement.Â  See, e.g., S.C. Code Ann. Â§
  5-15-130 (2004) (containing a notice requirement of specific hours).
The fact that there
  are multiple rules for computing time is not all together surprising.Â  As far
  back as the 1870 Code, South Carolinaâ€™s statutory law contained separate rules
  for computing time periods spelled out in procedural rules and time periods for
  the publication of legal notices.Â  See 1870 Code of Civ. Pro. Â§Â§
  421, 422.Â  Accordingly, old civil procedure cases relied on the version of the
  procedural rule then in effect, and old publication cases pulled from the
  applicable publication rule.Â  All of this
  simply means that the method for computing time in a particular case may be prescribed
  by statute, court rule, local ordinance, or some other authority, and the answer
  we supply today is that where a time prescription mentions only the passage of
  a number of days, a â€œdayâ€ means a calendar day, beginning and ending at
  midnight.

CONCLUSION
We
  hold that summary judgment was properly granted in favor of the City of North Charleston on the question whether less than thirty days elapsed between April 28,
  2005, the date Summerville published notice of its hearing, and May 27, 2005,
  the date Summerville enacted its annexation ordinance.Â  The order of the
  circuit court is
AFFIRMED.
TOAL, C.J., MOORE, WALLER and BEATTY, JJ., concur.


[1] Summerville attempts to draw a distinction between a requirement of â€œnot less
  than thirty daysâ€ and a fictional requirement of â€œat least thirty days,â€ but
  this distinction suffers from a similar flaw.Â  If a brief filed in court must
  be not less than four pages in length, a three and one-half page brief would
  not suffice.
[2] The requirement is now five days. Â See S.C. Const. Art. IV, Â§ 21.Â

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Supreme Court

	
		
			
				The State, Respondent,
				v.
				Derringer
      Young, Petitioner.
			
		
	


ON WRIT OF CERTIORARI TO THE COURT OF
  APPEALS

Appeal from Charleston County
Â Daniel F. Pieper, Circuit Court Judge
Opinion No. 26493
Heard April 3, 2008 - Filed May 19, 2008Â Â  
AFFIRMED AS MODIFIED


	
		
			
				Chief Appellate Defender Joseph L. Savitz III, of South Carolina
  Commission on Indigent Defense, Division of Appellate Defense, of Columbia, for
  Petitioner.
				Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney
  General John W. McIntosh, Assistant Deputy Attorney General Salley W. Elliott, Assistant
  Attorney General David Spencer, all of Columbia, and Ralph E. Hoisington, of
  Charleston, for Respondent.
			
		
	

CHIEF JUSTICE TOAL:Â Â Â Â  A
  jury found Appellant Derringer Young (Young) guilty of kidnapping and assault
  and battery of a high and aggravated nature (ABHAN) as a lesser included
  offense of criminal sexual conduct (CSC) stemming from a drug transaction with
  a female victim.Â  Young appealed on the grounds that the trial court improperly
  admitted evidence of prior convictions for CSC and criminal domestic violence
  (CDV).Â  The court of appeals affirmed Youngâ€™s conviction and this Court granted
  certiorari.Â  We affirm the decision of the court of appeals as modified.
Factual/Procedural
  Background
Young
  was charged with kidnapping, first-degree CSC, and possession with intent to
  distribute (PWID) stemming from a drug transaction with a female victim
  (Victim).Â  Young pled guilty to the PWID charge and went to trial for the
  remaining charges.Â  Young and Victim each testified at trial, giving different
  accounts of the night in question.Â  
Victim testified
  that following dinner with her husband one evening, she drove to downtown Charleston alone to purchase crack cocaine for herself and her husband.Â  She had purchased
  crack in this manner before and approached Young because he looked familiar
  from her past dealings.Â  Victim sampled crack from Young and requested an
  amount to buy.Â  Young did not have the desired amount on him, so Victim agreed
  to give him a ride in her vehicle to find more crack to purchase.Â  
While driving
  around, Victim testified that she and Young smoked some of Youngâ€™s crack together.Â 
  Victim described Young as having a pleasant demeanor and testified that they
  initially got along with no problems.Â  However, Victim claimed that after Young
  was able to locate and purchase the additional crack she requested, Young became
  angry when she told him she was going to take the crack home to smoke with her
  husband.Â  Victim testified that at that point, Young hit her across the face
  and in the back of the head.Â  Victim testified that Young forced his way into
  the driverâ€™s seat, drove to a secluded area, tied Victimâ€™s hands together, and
  raped her.Â  Afterwards, Young drove around downtown Charleston all night,
  buying and selling crack out of Victimâ€™s car while Victim remained in the front
  seat with her hands bound.Â  
Victim recounted
  that around nine oâ€™clock the next morning, a Charleston police officer spotted Young
  and Victim in Victimâ€™s car in a parking lot behind an abandoned warehouse.Â 
  Victim mouthed â€œplease help meâ€ to the officer.Â  When Young saw the officer, he
  jumped into the driverâ€™s seat and sped away.Â  Police located Young and Victim
  about ten minutes later and immediately arrested Young.Â  Police noticed red
  marks and bruising on Victimâ€™s wrists and neck, and Victim was taken
  immediately to MUSC and given a rape exam, which was inconclusive as to whether
  sexual assault had occurred.Â  Examiners also noted bruising on Victimâ€™s face,
  neck, and arms, as well as marks on each wrist.Â  
After
  the State called its last witness at trial, Young raised the issue of the
  admissibility of his prior convictions under Rule 609, SCRE, in an in camera hearing.Â  Young had prior convictions for third-degree CSC, third-degree
  burglary, possession of a stolen vehicle, and failure to register as a sex
  offender.Â  The trial court allowed the State to introduce evidence of Youngâ€™s
  convictions for third-degree burglary and for possession of a stolen vehicle as
  general impeachment evidence under Rule 609(a)(1) and (a)(2) for the purpose of
  attacking Youngâ€™s credibility as a witness.Â  The trial court did not allow the
  State to refer specifically to the prior CSC conviction, but instead allowed
  the State to impeach Youngâ€™s credibility by referring to the prior CSC
  conviction as â€œanother felony for which he has been convicted.â€[1]Â 
  The trial court also acknowledged that Young could open the door, via his
  testimony, to the admissibility of other prior convictions, including specific
  reference to the third-degree CSC conviction.
Following the trial
  courtâ€™s in camera ruling, Young testified to a drastically different version
  of the facts surrounding his encounter with Victim.Â  Young recounted that he
  sold crack to Victim and then rode in her car to a place where she could smoke
  the crack discretely.Â  After Young and Victim finished smoking the crack Victim
  had purchased, Young testified that Victim requested more crack, but she did
  not have any money.Â  Young agreed to get the drugs for her because he trusted
  her to pay him later.Â  Thereafter, for the next several hours, Young and Victim
  smoked crack supplied by Young.
At one point, after
  Young left the car to purchase drugs, another drug dealer began talking to
  Victim.Â  Young said he became angry because he thought Victim was trying to
  find another crack dealer.Â  Young further testified that at Victimâ€™s
  insistence, the other drug dealer rode with them to a secluded spot where Young
  exited the vehicle, and Victim performed oral sex on the other drug dealer in
  exchange for crack cocaine.Â Â Â  
After
  dropping off the other drug dealer, Young stated that he was upset with Victim
  for demeaning herself and for betraying their â€œbond.â€ Â They continued to drive
  around and smoke crack, and around 5 oâ€™clock in the morning, Victim became
  upset about making Young angry.Â  According to Young, Victim began crying and seeking
  Youngâ€™s forgiveness.Â  Young testified that he â€œhated[d] to see a female cryâ€
  and forgave her.
Following Youngâ€™s
  direct examination, the State argued that Young opened the door to admission of
  his prior convictions for CSC in the third degree and for CDV by introducing
  evidence of his good character towards women with his comment about hating to
  see a woman cry.Â  The trial judge ruled that Young had placed a character trait
  in issue and therefore allowed the State to impeach Young by asking him about
  his prior convictions for CDV and CSC. 
The
  jury found Young guilty of kidnapping and ABHAN as a lesser included offense of
  CSC.Â  The trial court sentenced Young to concurrent sentences of twenty-two
  years for kidnapping, ten years for ABHAN, and five years for the PWID charge.Â 
  Young appealed on the grounds that the trial court improperly admitted evidence
  of Youngâ€™s prior convictions for CDV and CSC for impeachment purpose.Â  The
  court of appeals affirmed Youngâ€™s convictions in State v. Young, 364
  S.C. 476, 613 S.E.2d 386 (Ct. App. 2005).Â  This Court granted certiorari to
  review the court of appealsâ€™ decision, and Young raises the following issue for
  review:

	Did the court
  of appeals err in affirming the admission of Youngâ€™s prior convictions for
  impeachment purposes after Young â€œopened the doorâ€ with evidence of his good
  character towards women?

Law/Analysis
Young
  argues that he did not open the door so that his prior conviction for CSC and
  CDV could be used to impeach him.Â  We agree.
Evidence of a
  defendantâ€™s character is generally not admissible to show a propensity to act
  accordingly.Â  Rule 404(a)(1), SCRE.Â  However, when the accused offers evidence
  of his good character regarding specific character traits relevant to the crime
  charged, the solicitor has the right to cross-examine him as to particular bad
  acts or conduct.Â  State v. Major, 301 S.C. 181, 391 S.E.2d 235 (1990).Â 
  The State is restricted to showing bad character only for the traits initially
  focused on by the accused, and impeachment may be done by introducing prior
  convictions with extrinsic evidence.Â  Id. at 185, 391 S.E.2d at
  238.
We find that
  Youngâ€™s testimony that he hated to see a woman cry did not open the door for
  the admission of his prior CDV and CSC convictions.Â  Reading Youngâ€™s testimony
  in its proper context, Young was not offering evidence of a specific character
  trait towards women in general.Â  Rather, the isolated statement used to justify
  admission of the prior CDV and CSC convictions was simply part of Youngâ€™s
  narrative recounting his version of the events that occurred on the night in
  question.Â  For this reason, the State was limited to presenting evidence
  admissible under Rule 609, SCRE, to impeach Youngâ€™s credibility.Â  Pursuant to
  Rule 609(a)(1), such evidence is limited to prior convictions for crimes
  punishable by imprisonment in excess of one year, subject to Rule 403.Â 
  Additionally, Rule 609(a)(2) permits evidence of convictions for crimes
  involving dishonesty.
In
  this case, questioning Young generally on â€œanother felony for which he ha[d]
  been convicted,â€ as the trial court properly permitted in the first instance
  pursuant to Rule 609, SCRE, was entirely sufficient to impeach Youngâ€™s
  credibility.Â  We find that the Stateâ€™s use of a specific prior conviction for
  the same offense that Young was currently standing trial for was only a
  thinly-veiled attempt to show propensity, rather than a sincere attempt at
  impeachment of Youngâ€™s credibility.Â  For this reason, we hold that the trial
  court erred in admitting Youngâ€™s prior CDV and CSC convictions to impeach
  Young.Â  State v. Dunlap, 353 S.C. 539, 542, 579 S.E.2d 318, 320 (2003)
  (ruling that when a prior crime is similar to the one for which the defendant
  is being tried, the danger of unfair prejudice to the defendant from
  impeachment by the prior offense weighs against its admission); Green v.
    State, 338 S.C. 428, 433-34, 527 S.E.2d 98, 101 (2000) (finding that in
  admitting evidence pursuant to Rule 609, the trial court must consider the
  impeachment value of the prior crime, the timing of the prior crime, the
  similarity between the past crime and the charged crime, the importance of the
  defendantâ€™s testimony, and the centrality of the credibility issue).
Young
  contends that because the trial court erred by admitting his prior CDV and CSC
  convictions, his convictions in this case should be reversed.Â  We disagree.
In
  order for this Court to reverse a case based on erroneous admission of
  evidence, prejudice must be shown.Â  State v. Bell, 302 S.C. 18, 27, 393
  S.E.2d 364, 369 (1990).Â  In this case, we find that the trial courtâ€™s error was
  harmless.Â  The jury took all the evidence into account and acquitted Young of
  CSC, indicating that the introduction of Youngâ€™s prior CDV and CSC convictions
  did not affect the jury.Â  Furthermore, there was substantial evidence in the
  record on which the jury could have found him guilty on the other charges.Â 
  Accordingly, we affirm Youngâ€™s convictions for kidnapping and ABHAN.

Conclusion
For
  the foregoing reasons, we hold that the trial court committed harmless error in
  allowing the State to introduce Youngâ€™s prior convictions 
for CDV and CSC.Â 
  Accordingly, we affirm the decision of the court of appeals as modified and
  affirm Youngâ€™s conviction for kidnapping and ABHAN.Â  
MOORE, WALLER, BEATTY, JJ., and Acting Justice Diane
  Schafer Goodstein, concur.


[1] The trial court did not allow introduction of the
  conviction for failure to register as a sex offender, finding that it was not a
  crime of dishonesty under Rule 609(a)(2), and that although the crime was punishable
  by imprisonment in excess of one year, the prejudicial effect of the conviction
  outweighed its probative value under Rule 403, SCRE.Â

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Supreme Court

	
		
			
				The State, Appellant,
				v.
				Berry Scott Bolin, Respondent.
			
		
	


Appeal From York County
Â John C. Hayes, III, Circuit Court Judge
Opinion No. 26494
Heard March 5, 2008 - Filed May 19, 2008Â Â  
AFFIRMED


	
		
			
				Attorney
  General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney General John W. McIntosh, Assistant
  Deputy Attorney General Donald J. Zelenka, Assistant Attorney General S.
  Creighton Waters, of Columbia; and Kevin Scott Brackett, Solicitor, of York,
  for appellant.
				Leland
  B. Greeley, of Rock Hill, for respondent.
			
		
	


JUSTICE
  MOORE:Â  Respondent was indicted for
  murder, assault and battery with intent to kill, possession of a firearm during
  commission of a violent offense, assault with intent to kill, discharging a
  firearm into an occupied vehicle, and possession of a pistol by a person under
  21 years of age pursuant to S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 16-23-30 (2003 & Supp. 2007).
Respondent argued
  that the possession of a pistol indictment should be quashed because Â§
  16-23-30(B) under which he was charged is unconstitutional.Â  The motion to
  quash was granted by the trial court.Â  The State appeals and we affirm.
ISSUE

	Did the trial court err by quashing
  the indictment for possession of a handgun while under the age of 21 on the
  ground that the criminal statute making such possession illegal is
  unconstitutional?

DISCUSSION
When the issue is
  the constitutionality of a statute,
  every presumption will be made in favor of its validity
  and no statute will be declared unconstitutional unless
  its invalidity appears so clearly as to
  leave no doubt that it conflicts with the constitution.Â  State v. Gaster, 349
  S.C. 545, 564 S.E.2d 87 (2002).Â  This presumption places the initial burden on
  the party challenging the constitutionality of
  the legislation to show it violates a provision of the Constitution.Â  State
    v. White, 348 S.C. 532, 560 S.E.2d 420, cert. denied, 537 U.S. 825 (2002).

	Section 16-23-30(A)
  provides:
	
		[i]t is
  unlawful for a person to knowingly sell, offer to sell, deliver, lease, rent,
  barter, exchange, or transport for sale into this State any handgun to:Â  (3) a
  person under the age of twenty-one, but this shall not apply to the issue of
  handguns to members of the [military or other like organizations or to those
  receiving instruction on handgun use under the immediate supervision of a
  parent or adult instructor].
	

Subsection (B) states that
  â€œ[i]t is unlawful for a person enumerated in subsection (A) to possess or
  acquire handguns within this State.â€[1]
Respondent argues
  that because he was old enough to be sui juris and the state
  constitution granted him the right to bear arms, then he could not be charged
  with a crime for handgun possession.Â  See S.C. Const. Art. I, Â§ 20 (a well-regulated militia being necessary to the security of a free
  State, the right of the people to keep and bear
  arms shall not be infringed).
The portions of Â§
  16-23-30 regarding persons under the age of 21 do not violate the constitutional
  right of a person under the age of 21 to keep and bear arms.Â  While a person
  under the age of 21 is prohibited from possessing a handgun, except in certain
  circumstances, this does not prevent a person under the age of 21 from possessing
  other types of guns.Â  Our constitution simply requires that a personâ€™s right to
  keep and bear â€œarmsâ€ not be infringed upon.Â  The legislatureâ€™s regulation of
  who may have access to handguns does not infringe upon that right because
  persons under the age of 21 have access to other types of guns.Â  Cf. State
    v. Johnson, 76 S.C. 39, 56 S.E. 544 (1907) (city ordinance prohibiting
  firing of guns within city limits is not unconstitutional as infringing on
  right to bear arms); State v. Johnson, 16 S.C. 187 (1881) (purpose of
  act was to prohibit, as far as consistent with a citizenâ€™s right to bear arms,
  the carrying of deadly weapons, with a view to prevent acts of violence).[2]Â  Accordingly, Â§ 16-23-30 does not violate S.C. Const. Art. I, Â§
  20, regarding a personâ€™s right to keep and bear arms.
Respondent further
  argues that Â§ 16-23-30 violates the state constitution because the age group of
  18- to 20-year-olds is being treated differently than adults aged 21 and
  above.Â  South Carolina Const. Art. XVII, Â§ 14, provides:

	Every
  citizen who is eighteen years of age or older, not laboring under disabilities
  prescribed in this Constitution or otherwise established by law, Â shall be deemed
	sui juris and endowed with full legal rights and responsibilities, provided, 
	that
  the General Assembly may restrict the sale of alcoholic beverages to persons
  until age twenty-one.

Article XVII, Â§ 14,
  specifically makes reference to the fact the General Assembly can restrict the
  sale of alcoholic beverages to persons until age 21.Â  By expressly allowing the
  regulation of the sale of alcoholic beverages to the 18- to 20-year-old age
  group and not stating any other situation in which the General Assembly may restrict
  the rights of this age group, the state constitution precludes the General
  Assembly from prohibiting this age groupâ€™s possession of handguns.Â  See Hodges v. Rainey, 341 S.C. 79, 533 S.E.2d 578
    (2000) (the canon of construction â€œexpressio unius est exclusio
      alteriusâ€ or â€œ inclusio unius est
        exclusio alteriusâ€ holds that â€œto express or include one thing implies the
  exclusion of another, or of the alternativeâ€); see also Strickland v.
    Strickland, 375 S.C. 76, 650 S.E.2d 465 (2007) (when interpreting a
  statute, the words must be given their plain and ordinary meaning without
  resorting to subtle or forced construction which limit or expand the statuteâ€™s
  operation).
We find the General
  Assemblyâ€™s prohibition on hand gun possession by the 18-to 20-year old age
  group does not infringe upon the right to bear arms; however, Â§ 16-23-30
  violates the plain language of Article XVII, Â§ 14, of our state constitution.Â 
  Accordingly, the decision of the trial court is

AFFIRMED.
TOAL, C.J.,
  WALLER, BEATTY, JJ., and Acting Justice E. C. Burnett, III, concur.


[1] The General Assembly recently passed and the Governor
  signed a bill amending Â§ 16-23-30.Â  The amendment makes it unlawful for a
  person under the age of eighteen to possess a handgun.Â  Therefore, the 18-to
  20-year-old age group may now legally possess a handgun.Â  However, this
  amendment does not apply to the instant case because the General Assembly
  provided that this amendment does not affect pending actions. 
[2] See also Robertson v. City
  and County of Denver, 874 P.2d 325 (Colo. 1994) (ban of assault weapons was
  a reasonable exercise of police power despite the right to bear arms); Benjamin
    v. Bailey, 662 A.2d 1226 (Conn. 1995) (ban on sale and possession of
  assault weapons did not infringe on right to bear arms because access to a wide
  array of weapons was still permitted); Mosby v. Devine, 851 A.2d 1031
  (R.I. 2004) (right to possess a handgun, whether fundamental or not, is not
  absolute and is subject to reasonable regulation; statute was not a total ban
  on the right to bear arms).

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Supreme Court


  
    
      
        Jeremy Tisdale, Petitioner,
        v.
        State of South Carolina, Respondent.
      
    
  


Appeal from Berkeley County
Roger M. Young, Sr., Circuit Court Judge

ON WRIT OF CERTIORARI

Opinion No.Â  26495
Submitted April 16, 2008 - Filed May 27, 2008 

REVERSED


  
    
      
        Appellate Defender Robert M. Pachak, of South Carolina Commission
          on Indigent Defense, Division of Appellate Defense, of Columbia, for
          petitioner.
        Attorney General Henry
          Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney General John W. McIntosh, Assistant
          Deputy Attorney General Salley W. Elliott, and Assistant Attorney General Matthew
          J. Friedman, all of Columbia, for respondent.
      
    
  


JUSTICE MOORE:Â  Petitioner
  was convicted of murder and sentenced to life without parole.Â  His direct
  appeal was dismissed after an Anders review.[1]Â 
  Petitioner then filed this application for post-conviction relief (PCR)
  claiming counsel were ineffective for failing to request a charge on accident
  or involuntary manslaughter.Â  PCR was denied.Â  We reverse.
FACTS
The victim in this case was Lavelle Anderson
  (Victim).Â  His decomposing nude body was found in a ditch in Berkeley County on October 2, 2000.Â  He had been shot twice in the head.Â  
Petitioner and his co-defendant,
  Anthony Dawson, were charged with murdering Victim on September 27 and
  disposing of the body.Â  The Stateâ€™s theory of the case was that Victimâ€™s murder
  was revenge for the killing of petitionerâ€™s brother in a drive-by shooting a
  few days earlier.Â  
At trial, Dawson testified for the
  State.Â  He stated that after the wake for petitionerâ€™s brother, he and
  petitioner picked up Victim in a borrowed car.Â  Dawson was reclined in the
  backseat because he had a headache, so Victim got in the front seat.Â  As they
  drove down the interstate, Dawson heard petitioner and Victim talking but could
  not hear their words until their voices became raised.Â  Victim began yelling
  and called petitioner a â€œbitch.â€Â  Victim then punched petitioner in the face.Â 
  Petitioner pinned Victim against the passenger side of the car and was pulling
  the car onto the shoulder of the road when Victim pulled a gun and shot at
  petitioner.Â  Petitioner and Victim fought over the gun and one or two shots were
  fired.Â  Dawson stated he did not know who had the gun when the shots were
  fired, but he saw the gun in petitionerâ€™s hand after the shooting.Â  Petitioner
  and Dawson put Victimâ€™s body in the trunk of the car and drove to a friendâ€™s
  house for help disposing of the body. 
Petitioner testified he picked up
  Victim because Victim had called him asking for a favor.Â  After Victim was in
  the car and stated where he wanted to go, petitioner did not want to do it.Â 
  Victim then began yelling and punched petitioner in the face.Â  When petitioner
  saw Victim pull a gun, they struggled over the weapon.Â  The gun went off while
  it was still in Victimâ€™s hand and then Victim was still.Â  On cross-examination,
  the solicitor asked:Â  â€œYour testimony is that that gun was never in your
  hand?â€Â  Petitioner answered:Â  â€œIt was never in my hand until he was just
  motionless.â€Â  
During closing,
the solicitor argued:

  [T]hey want you to believe that this
    was an accident.Â  It is not self-defense.Â  It is not voluntary manslaughter.Â 
    And it is not involuntary manslaughter.Â  They want you to believe that it was
    an accident and it is not murder.Â  No evidence supports that it was anything
    other than an intentional act. 

The trial judge charged voluntary manslaughter as a lesser
  offense and self-defense.Â  On PCR, petitioner claimed counsel were ineffective
  for failing to request charges on accident and involuntary manslaughter.Â  
At the PCR hearing, Counsel Brown
  testified he was surprised by petitionerâ€™s testimony that the gun was in
  Victimâ€™s hand and not petitionerâ€™s when it fired.Â  It did not occur to counsel
  to request a charge on accident or involuntary manslaughter.Â  Co-counsel
  confirmed that there was no discussion of accident or involuntary manslaughter. 
The PCR judge found the fact that
  Victim was shot twice â€œin the back of the headâ€[2] was completely inconsistent with either accident or involuntary manslaughter
  and therefore counsel were not ineffective in failing to request these
  charges.Â  
ISSUE

  Were counsel ineffective for
    failing to request charges on accident and/or involuntary manslaughter?

DISCUSSION
Involuntary manslaughter is a
  lesser included offense of murder only if there is evidence the killing was
  unintentional.Â  State v. Pickens, 320 S.C. 528, 466 S.E.3d 364 (1996).[3]Â 
  Evidence of a struggle between the defendant and the victim over a weapon
  supports submission of an involuntary manslaughter charge.Â  Casey v. State,
  305 S.C. 445, 409 S.E.2d 391 (1991).Â  Here, there is evidence of a struggle
  over the gun.Â  The fact that Victimâ€™s wounds may have been inconsistent with
  petitionerâ€™s testimony that the gun fired while in Victimâ€™s hand is not
  overwhelming evidence that petitioner intentionally killed Victim. 
Without citation of authority, the State argues
  that because the jury rejected petitionerâ€™s claim of self-defense and found him
  guilty of murder, the jury must have found malice and therefore petitioner
  cannot show prejudice from the failure to submit involuntary manslaughter.[4]Â 
  We disagree.Â  The Stateâ€™s argument essentially suggests that if a defendant is
  found guilty of the greater offense, he can never challenge the failure to
  submit a lesser offense because the jury must have found all the elements of
  the greater.Â  To the contrary, the relevant test is whether there is any evidence that the defendant committed the lesser rather than the greater
  offense.Â  Casey v. State, supra.Â  Here, the evidence of a
  struggle for the gun supports submission of a charge of involuntary
  manslaughter.
Further, evidence of an accidental discharge of a
  gun will support a charge of accident where the defendant lawfully arms himself
  in self-defense.Â  State v. Burriss, 334 S.C. 256, 513 S.E.2d 104 (1999); see also State v. Cameron, 137 S.C. 371, 135 S.E. 364 (1926)
  (approving charge of accident where gun accidentally discharged during
  struggle).Â  Here, the evidence indicates Victim was the aggressor by punching
  petitioner in the face and then shooting at him.Â  This evidence, along with
  evidence the gun discharged accidentally, supports a charge of accident.
The denial of PCR is REVERSED.
 TOAL, C.J., WALLER, PLEICONES and BEATTY, JJ.,
  concur.


[1]Anders v. California, 386 U.S. 738 (1967).
[2]A pathologist testified at trial that the bullet
  wounds were to the left side of the head slightly behind the ear.
[3]Involuntary manslaughter is the killing of another
  without malice and unintentionally while engaged in either:Â  (1) an unlawful
  act not amounting to a felony and not naturally tending to cause death or great
  bodily harm;Â  or (2) a lawful act with reckless disregard for the safety of
  others.Â  State v. Reese, 370 S.C. 31, 633 S.E.2d 898 (2006).
[4]We rejected this analysis in the context of murder and voluntary manslaughter.Â  State v. Lowry, 315 S.C. 396, 434 S.E.2d
  272 (1993).Â Â

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Supreme Court


  
    
      
        The State of South Carolina, Respondent,
        v.
        Colie G.
          Martin, Jr. and Colie G. Martin, III, Appellants.
      
    
  


Appeal From Richland County
Â Larry R. Patterson, Circuit Court Judge

Opinion No. 26496
Heard April 2, 2008 - Filed May 27, 2008Â Â  

REVERSED


  
    
      
        Brian
          C. Gambrell, of Hamilton & Associates, of Columbia, for Appellants.
        Assistant
          Solicitor Jill Andrews, of Columbia, and John F. Kuppens, Joann E. Johnston, and
          A. Mattison Bogan, all of Nelson Mullins Riley & Scarborough LLP, all Â of Columbia, for Respondent.
      
    
  


JUSTICE
  WALLER: This is a direct appeal from two orders of the circuit court which
  was acting in an appellate capacity to review a magistrateâ€™s decision.Â  We
  reverse and remand to the magistrate court.

FACTUAL/PROCEDURAL BACKGROUND
The procedural history of this case is a bit convoluted.Â 
  Factually, the matter started as a criminal investigation with a search warrant
  issued by a magistrate on August 21, 2003, based on allegations of animal
  cruelty.Â  On the same date, the magistrate issued an order which placed
  approximately 60 horses in the protective custody of South Carolina Awareness
  and Rescue for Equines, Inc. (SCARE).Â  The order stated the following in
  pertinent part:

  On August 21, 2003 a Search Warrant was issued against the
    Defendant(s) â€¦ for the seizure of neglected and maltreated livestock,
    including, but not limited to horses.
  IT IS ORDERED THAT the livestock, including but not limited to the
    horses, are [sic] hereby placed in the protective custody of [SCARE], and
    further that the animals remain on the property for assessment and medial
    treatment and care, as deemed necessary by SCARE and their [sic] agents.
  IT IS FURTHER ORDERED that agents acting for or on behalf of SCARE
    will have access to these animals for the purposes stated above, and that the
    removal of these animals are [sic] at the sole discretion of SCARE and its
    agents.

(â€œAugust Orderâ€).
When the first search warrant was executed on Friday, August 22,
  2003, SCARE effectuated an â€œon-siteâ€ seizure of the horses pursuant to the
  August Order.Â  This allowed for on-site assessments by veterinarians during the
